{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3283679,"name":"Josh Sirota","username":"gdgr","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/f1d935/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-01-13T23:38:22.740Z","cooked":"

Hi all,

We have a YAGSL-based swerve robot running with Neo/SparkMax. It was running perfectly with all of the 2023 libraries. After updating everything, the drive motors no longer drive, though everything else appears to work.

This uses the SparkMax in closed-loop PID-based velocity mode, where the setpoint is set in m/s and there’s a VelocityConversionFactor, which appears to be correct (approximately 0.0008). I find that if I set the velocity MUCH higher (like, 50x, or 200 m/s) than what it should be, then the motors seem to spin. Same thing even if I use the REV hardware client – with a conversion factor of approx .0008, setting a velocity setpoint of single digits results in no motion at all.

While this COULD be a problem with some change in YAGSL, or in our robot code, after a bunch of debugging it FEELS like this is a problem with the rev firmware update, which we also did as part of the migration to 2024.

Has anyone else encountered a problem after updating sparkmax/neo-based stuff to the 2024 stuff like this? Any suggestions?

YAGSL 2024 changed how feedforward works. You need to add a value for “F” in pidfproperties.json. Try 0.15 or 0.2

Well, that certainly made a big difference. Wish I’d known that.

It still doesn’t quite work right. It’s very inconsistent. Sometimes the wheels don’t agree on their direction, sometimes they do.

Are there any other changes of that sort of nature that have happened in the last month or two on YAGSL for which my previous settings just won’t work?
